editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Gathered partely (by translation) in the fyne outlandish gardins of Euripides, Ouid, Petrarke, Ariosto, and others: and partly by inuention, out of our owne fruitefull orchardes in Englande: yelding sundrie svveete sauours of tragical, comical, and morall discourses ...
Hundreth sundrie flowres bounde up in one small poesie
Iocasta.
Jocasta.
Hundreth sundrie flowres bounde up in one small poesie.
Discourse of the aduentures passed by Master F.I.
Discourse of the adventures passed by Master F.I.
titleStmt.author: Gascoigne, George, 1542?-1577.

publicationStmt.publisher: Imprinted [by Henrie Bynneman [and Henry Middleton]] for Richarde Smith,

note.p: The name of the author and translator, George Gascoigne, appears in headings throughout the book.
Colophon, 1X4v, reads "Printed by Henrie Bynneman for Richarde Smith"; Middleton printed 2A-S ("Studies in Bibliography" 45 (1992), p. 71-104).

In two registers. Within the first, "Iocasta" has separate divisional title but continuous pagination. The second commences on p. 201 with caption title "A discourse of the aduentures passed by Master F.I.".
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

div.head: Supposes: a comedy written in the Italian tongue by Ariosto, and englished by George Gascoygne of Gray's inn esquire, and there presented.

list.item: Cleander, the doctor, suitor to Polynesta.
Dulipo, feigned servant and lover of Polynesta.
Erostrato, feigned master and suitor to Polynesta.
Dalio and Crapyno servants to feigned Erostrato.
Nevola, and two other his servants.
Psyteria, an old hag in his house.
Phylogano, a Scycilian gentleman, father to Erostrato.

div.head: The prologue or argument.
div.p: I suppose you are assembled here, supposing to reap the fruit of my travails: and to be plain, I mean presently to present you with a comedy called supposes, the very name whereof may peradventure drive into every of your heads a sundry suppose, to suppose the meaning of our supposes. Some percase will suppose we mean to occupy your ears with sophistical handling of subtle suppositions. Some other will suppose we go about to decipher unto you some quaint conceits, which hitherto have been only supposed as it were in shadows: and some I see smiling as though they supposed we would trouble you with the vain suppose of some wanton suppose. But understand, this our suppose is nothing else but a mistaking or imagination of one thing for another: for you shall see the master supposed for the servant, the servant for the master: the freeman for a slave, and the bondslave for a freeman: the stranger for a well known friend, and the familiar for a stranger. But what? I suppose that even already you suppose me very fond, that have so simply disclosed unto you the subtleties of these our supposes: where otherwise in deed I suppose you should have heard almost the last of our supposes, before you could have supposed any of them aright. Let this then suffice.

div.head: Scaena. i.
div.stage: Balia, the nurse. Polynesta, the young woman.
div.p: Here is nobody , come forth Polynesta, let us look about, to be sure lest any man hear our talk: for I think within the house the tables, the planks, the beds, the portals, yea and the cupboards themselves have ears.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You might as well have said, the windows and the doors: do you not see how they harken?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Well you jest fair, but I would advise you take heed, I have bidden you a thousand times beware, you will be spied one day talking with Dulipo.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: And why should I not talk with Dulipo as well as with any other, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I have given you a wherefore for this why many times, but go too, follow your own advice till you overwhelm us all with sudden mishap.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: A great mishap I promise you: marry God's blessing on their heart that set such a brooch on my cap.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Well, look well about you: a man would think it were enough for you secretly to rejoice, that by my help you have passed so many pleasant nights together, and yet by my troth I do it more than half against my will, for I would rather you had settled your fancy in some noble family, yea and it is no small grief unto me, that rejecting the suits of so many nobles and gentlemen, you have chosen for your darling a poor servant of your fathers, by whom shame and infamy is the best dower you can look for to attain.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
And I pray you whom may I thank but gentle nurse, that continually praising him, what for his personage, his courtesy, and above all, the extreme passions of
his mind, in fine you would never cease till I accepted him, delighted in him, and at length desired him with no less affection, than he erst desired me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I can not deny, but at the beginning I did recommend him unto you (As in deed I may say that for myself I have a pitiful heart) seeing the depth of his unbridled affection, and that continually he never ceased to fill mine ears with lamentable complaints.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay rather that he filled your purse with bribes and rewards.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Well you may judge of nurse as you list: in deed I have thought it always a deed of charity to help the miserable young men, whose tender youth consumeth with the furious flames of love: but be you sure if I had thought you would have passed to the terms you now stand in, pity nor pension, penny nor pater noster should ever have made nurse once to open her mouth in the cause.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: No of honesty, I pray you, who first brought him into my chamber? who first taught him the way to my bed but you? fie nurse fie, never speak of it for shame, you will make me tell a wise tale anon.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And have I these thanks for my good will? why then I see well I shall be counted the cause of all mishap.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay rather the author of my good hap gentle nurse, for I would thou knewest I love not Dulipo, nor any of so mean estate, but have bestowed my love more worthily than thou deemest, but I will say no more at this time.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Then I am glad you have changed your mind yet.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Nay I neither have changed, nor will change it.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Then I understand you not, how said you?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Marry I say that I love not Dulipo, nor any such as he, and yet I neither have changed nor will change my mind.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
I can not tell, you love to lie with Dulipo very
well: this gear is Greek to me, either it hangs not well together, or I am very dull of under standing, speak plain I pray you.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I can speak no plainer, I have sworn to thecontrary.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: How? make you so dainty to tell it nurse, lest she should reveal it? you have trusted me as far as may be, I may show to you, in things that touch your honour if they were known: and make you strange to tell me this? I am sure it is but a trifle in comparison of those things whereof heretofore you have made me privy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Well, it is of greater importance than you think nurse, yet would I tell it you under condition and promise that you shall not tell it again, nor give any sign or token to be suspected that you know it.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I promise you of my honesty, say on.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Well hear you me then: this young man whom you have always taken for Dulipo, is a noble born Sicilian, his right name Erostrato, son to Philogono, one of the worthiest men in that country.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: How Erostrato? is it not our neighbour, which?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Hold thy talking nurse, and hearken to me, that I may explain the whole case unto thee: the man whom to this day you have supposed to be Dulipo, is (As I say) Erostrato, a gentleman that came from Sicilia to study in this city, and even at his first arrival met me in the street, fell enamoured of me, and of such vehement force were the passions he suffered, that immediately he cast aside both long gown and books, and determined on me only to apply his study: and to the end he might the more commodiously both see me and talk with me, he exchanged both name, habit, clothes and credit with his servant Dulipo, whom only he brought with him out of Sicilia, and so with the turning of a hand, of Erostrato a gentleman, he became Dulipo a serving man, and soon after sought service of my father, and obtained it.

sp.speaker: Ba
sp.p: Are you sure of this?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Yea out of doubt, on the other side Dulipo took upon him the name of Erostrato his master, the habit, the credit, books, and all things needful to a student, and in short space profited very much, and is now esteemed as you see.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Are there no other Sicylians here: nor none that pass this way, which may discover them?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Very few that pass this way, and few or none that tarry here any time.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: This hath been a strange adventure, but I pray you how hang these things together? that the student whom you say to be the servant, and not the master, is become an earnest suitor to you, and requireth you of your father in marriage?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: That is a policy devised between them, to put doctor Dotipole out of conceit, the old dotard, he that so instantly doth lie upon my father for me: but look where he comes, as God help me it is he, out upon him, what a lusty younker is this? yet I had rather be a nun a thousand times, than be cumbered with such a coistrel.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Daughter you have reason, but let us go in before he come any nearer.

div.stage: Polynesta goeth in, and Balya stayeth a little while after, speaking a word or two to the doctor, and then departeth.

div.head: Scaena. ij.
div.stage: Cleander, doctor. Pasiphilo, parasite. Balya, nurse.
div.p: Were there dames here, or did mine eyes dazzle?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nay sir here were Polynesta and her nurse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Was my Polynesta here? alas I knew her not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
He must have better eyesight that should marry
your Polynesta, or else he may chance to oversee the best point in his tables sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sir it is no marvel, the air is very misty today: I myself knew her better by her apparel than by her face.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: In good faith and I thank God I have mine eye sight good and perfect, little worse than when I was but twenty years old.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: How can it be otherwise? you are but young.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am fifty years old.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: He tells ten less than he is.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What sayst thou of ten less?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I say I would have thought you ten less, you look like one of six and thirty, or seven and thirty at the most.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am no less than I tell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You are like enough to live fifty more, show me your hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why is Pasiphilo a chiromancer?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What is not Pasiphilo? I pray you show me it a little.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Here it is.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O how straight and infract is this line of life, you will live to the years of Melchisedech.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou wouldst say, Methusalem.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why is it not all one?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I perceive you are no very good bibler Pasiphilo.

sp.speaker: Pa
sp.p: Yes sir an excellent good bibler, specially in a bottle: o what a mount of Venus here is, but this light serveth not very well, I will behold it another day, when the air is clearer, and tell you somewhat, peradventure to your contentation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You shall do me great pleasure: but tell me, I pray thée Pasiphilo, whom dost thou think Polynesta liketh better, Erostrato or me?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why you out of doubt: she is a gentlewoman of a noble mind, and maketh greater account of the reputation she shall have in marrying your worship, than that poor scholar, whose birth and parentage God knoweth, and very few else.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yet he taketh it upon him bravely in the country.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yea, where no man knoweth the contrary: but let him brave it, boast his birth, and do what he can, the virtue and knowledge that is within this body of yours, is worth more than all the country he came from.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It becometh not a man to praise himself: but in deed I may say, and say truly, that my knowledge hath stood me in better steed at a pinch, than could all the goods in the world. I came out of Otranto when the Turks won it, and first I came to Padua, after hither; where by reading, counselling, and pleading, within twenty years I have gathered and gained as good as ten thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yea marry, this is the right knowledge, philosophy, poetry, logic, and all the rest, are but pickling sciences in comparison to this.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But pickling in deed, whereof we have a verse:
sp.l: The trade of law doth fill the boisterous bags,
They swim in silk, when others roist in rags.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O excellent verse, who made it? Virgil?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Virgil? tush it is written in one of our gloss.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sure whosoever wrote it, the moral is excellent, and worthy to be written in letters of gold: but to the purpose: I think you shall never recover the wealth that you lost at Otranto.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I think I have doubled it, or rather made it four times as much: but in deed, I lost mine only son there, a child of five years old.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O great pity.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea, I had rather lost all the goods in the world.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Alas, alas, by God and grafts of such a stock are very gaysome in these days.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I know not whether he were slain, or the Turks took him and kept him as a bond slave.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Alas, I could weep for compassion, but there is no remedy but patience, you shall get many by this young damsel with the grace of God.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea, if I get her.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Get her? why doubt you of that?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, her father holds me off with delays, so that I must needs doubt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Content yourself sir, he is a wise man, and desirous to place his daughter well, he will not be too rash in his determination, he will think well of the matter, and let him think, for the longer he thinketh, the more good of you shall he think: whose wealth, whose virtue, whose skill, or whose estimation can he compare to yours in this city?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And hast thou not told him that I would make his daughter a dower of two thousand ducats?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why, even now, I came but from thence since.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What said he?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nothing, but that Erostrato had proffered the like.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Erostrato? how can he make any dower, and his father yet alive?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Think you I did not tell him so? yes I warrant you, I forgotten nothing that may further your cause, and doubt you not, Erostrato shall never have her unless it be in a dream.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well gentle Pasiphilo; go thy ways and tell Damon I require nothing but his daughter, I will none of his goods: I shall enrich her of mine own: and if this dower of two thousand ducats seem not sufficient, I will make it five hundreth more, yea a thousand, or whatsoever he will demand rather than fail: go to Pasiphilo, show thyself friendly in working this feat for me, spare for no cost, since I have gone thus far, I will be loath to be out bidden. go

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Where shall I come to you again?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: At my house.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Shall I come at dinner time?

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: I would bid thee to dinner, but it is a saint's even which I have ever fasted.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Fast till thou famish.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hark.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: He speaketh of a dead man's fast.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou hearest me not.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Nor thou understandest me not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I dare say thou art angry I bid thee not to dinner, but come if thou wilt, thou shalt take such as thou findest.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What? think you I know not where to dine?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes Pasiphilo thou art not to seek.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No be you sure, there are enough will pray me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That I know well enough Pasiphilo, but thou canst not be better welcome in any place than to me, I will tarry for thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Well, since you will needs, I will come.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Dispatch then, and bring no news but good.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Better than my reward by the rood.

div.head: Scaena. iij.
div.p:
O miserable covetous wretch, he findeth an excuse by s Nicholas fast, because I should not dine with him, as though I should dine at his own dish: he maketh goodly feasts I promise you, it is no wonder though he think me bound unto him for my fare: for over and besides that his provision is as scant as may be, yet there is great difference
between his diet and mine. I never so much as sip of the wine that he tasteth, I feed at the board's end with brown bread: Marry I reach always to his own dish, for there are no more but that only on the table: yet he thinks that for one such dinner I am bound to do him all the service that I can, and thinks me sufficiently rewarded for all my travel, with one such festival promotion: and yet peradventure some men think I have great gains under him: but I may say and swear, that this dozen year I have not gained so much in value as the points at my hose (Which are but thrée with codpiece point and all): he thinks that I may feed upon his favour and fair words: but if I could not otherwise provide for one, Pasiphilo were in a wise case. Pasiphilo hath more pastures to pass in than one, I warrant you: I am of household with this scholar Erostrato, his rival, as well as with dominae Cleander, now with the one, and then with the other, according as I see their cators provide good cheer at the market: and I find the means so to handle the matter, that I am welcome to both. If the one see me talk with the other, I make him believe it is to hearken news in the furtherance of his cause, and thus I become a broker on both sides. Well, let them both apply the matter as well as they can, for in deed I will travel for none of them both: yet will I seem to work wonders on each hand. But is not this one of Damon's servants that cometh forth? it is, of him I shall understand where his master is. Whither goeth this jolly gallant?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I come to seek somebody that may accompany my master at dinner, he is alone, and would fain have good company.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Seek no further, you could never have found one better than me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I have no commission to bring so many.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: How many? I will come alone.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: How canst thou come alone that hast continually a legion of ravening wolves within thee?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Thou dost as servants commonly do, hate all that love to visit their masters.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Because they have too many tooth as you think.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay because they have to many tongues.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Tongues? I pray you what did my tongue ever hurt you.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I speak but merrily with you Pasiphilo, go in, my master is ready to dine.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What? dineth he so early?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: He that riseth early, dineth early.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I would I were his man, master doctor never dineth till noon, and how dilicately then god knoweth, I will be bold to go in, for I count myself bidden.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: You were best so.

div.p:
Hard hap had I when I first began this unfortunate enterprise, for I supposed the readiest medicine to my miserable effects had been to change name, clothes, and credit with my servant, and to place myself in Damon's service, thinking that as shivering cold by glowing fire, thirst by drink, hunger by pleasant repasts, and a thousand such like passions find remedy by their contraries, so my restless desire might have found quiet by continual contemplation. But alas, I find that only love is unsatiable, for as the fly playeth with the flame till at last she is cause of her own decay, so the lover that thinketh with kissing and colling to content his unbridled appetite, is commonly seen the only cause of his own consumption: two years are now past since under the colour of Damon's service I have been a sworn servant to Cupid, of whom I have received as much favour and grace as ever man found in his service, I have free liberty at all times to behold my desired, to talk with her, to embrace her, yea (Be it spoken in secret) to lie with her, I reap the fruits of my desire, yet as my joys abound, even so
my pains increase, I fare like the covetous man, that having all the world at will, is never yet content, the more I have, the more I desire. Alas, what wretched estate have I brought myself unto, if in the end of all my far fetches, she be given by her father to this old doting doctor, this buzzard, this bribing villain, that by so many means seeketh to obtain her at her father's hands? I know she loveth me best of all others, but what may that prevail when perforce she shall be constrained to marry another? Alas thepleasant taste of my sugared joys doth yet remain so perfect in my remembrance, that the least sop of sorrow seemeth more sour thā gall in my mouth: if I had never known delight, with better contentation might I have passed these dreadful dolours. And if this old. M. impsimus (Whom the pocks consume) should win her, then may I say, farewell the pleasant talk, the kind embracings, yea farewell the sight of my Polynesta, for he like a jealous wretch will pen her up, that I think the birds of the air shall not win the sight of her. I hoped to have cast a block in his way, by the means that my servant, who is supposed to be Erostrato, and with my habit and credit is well esteemed, should proffer himself a suitor, at the least to countervail the doctor's proffers: but my master knowing the wealth of the one, and doubting the state of the other, is determined to be fed no longer with fair words, but to accept the doctor, (Whom he right well knoweth) for his son in law: well, my servant promised me yesterday to devise yet again some new conspiracy to drive master doctor out of conceit, and to lay a snare that the fox himself might be caught in, what it is, I know not, nor I saw him not since he went about it: I will go see if he be within, that at least if he help me not, he may yet prolong my life for this once. But here cometh his lackey, ho Jack hark, where is Erostrato?
div.stage: Here must Crapine be coming in with a basket and a stick in his hand.

div.head: Scaena. iiij.
div.p: Erostrato? marry he is in his skin.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Ah whoreson boy, I say, how shall I find Erostrato?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Find him? how mean you, by the week or by the year.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: You crack halter, if I catch you by the ears, I shall make you answer me directly.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: In deed?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Tarry me a little.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: In faith sir I have no leisure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Shall we try who can run fastest?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your legs be longer than mine, you should have given me the advantage.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Go to, tell me where is Erostrato?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I left him in the street, where he gave me this casket, this basket I would have said, and bade me bear it to Dalio, and return to him at the Duke's palace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: If thou see him, tell him I must needs speak with him immediately: or abide awhile, I will go seek him myself, rather than be suspected by going to his house.

div.stage: Crapino departeth, and Dulipo also: after Dulipo cometh in again seeking Erostrato.

div.head: Scaena. i
div.p:
I think if I had as many eyes as Argus, I could not have sought a man more narrowly in every street and every by lane, there are not many gentlemen, scholars,
nor merchants in the city of Ferrara, but I have met with them, except him, peradventure he is come home another way: but look where he cometh at the last.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: In good time have I spied my good master.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: For the love of God call me Dulipo, not master, maintain the credit that thou haste hitherto kept, and let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yet sir let me sometimes do my duty unto you, especially where nobody heareth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, but so long the parrot useth to cry knap in sport, that at the last she calleth her master knave in earnest: so long you will use to call me master, that at the last we shall be heard. What news?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: In deed?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yea excellent, we have as good as won the wager.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: O, how happy were I if this were true.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Hear you me, yesternight in the evening I walked out, and found Pasiphilo, and with small entreating I had him home to supper, where by such means as I used, he became my great friend, and told me the whole order of our adversary's determination: yea and what Damon doth intend to do also, and hath promised me that from time to time, what he can espy he will bring me word of it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I can not tell whether you know him or no, he is not to trust unto, a very flattering and a lying knave.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I know him very well, he can not deceive me, and this that he hath told me I know must needs be true.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And what was it in effect?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: That Damon had purposed to give his daughter in marriage to this doctor, upon thedower that he hath proffered.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Are these your good news? your excellent news?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Stay awhile, you will understand me before you hear me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Well, say on.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I answered to that, I was ready to make her the like dower.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Abide, you hear not the worst yet.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: O God, is there any worse behind?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Worse? why what assurance could you suppose that I might make without some special consent from Philogono my father?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay you can tell, you are better scholar than I.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: In deed you have lost your time: for the books that you toss nowadays , treat of small science.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Leave thy jesting, and proceed.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I said further, that I received letters lately from my father, whereby I understood that he would be here very shortly to perform all that I had proffered: therefore I required him to request Damon on my behalf, that he would stay his promise to the doctor for a fortnight or more.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: This is somewhat yet, for by this means I shall be sure to linger and live in hope one fortnight longer, but at the fortnight's end when Philogono cometh not, how shall I then do? yea and though he came, how may I any way hope of his consent, when he shall see, that to follow this amorous enterprise, I have set aside all study, all remembrance of my duty, and all dread of shame. Alas, alas, I may go hang myself.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Comfort yourself man, and trust in me: there is a salve for every sore, and doubt you not, to this mischief we shall find a remedy.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: O friend revive me, that hitherto since I first attempted this matter have been continually dying.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p:
Well, harken a while then: this morning I took my horse and road into the fields to solace myself, and as I passed the ford beyonds s. Anthony's gate, I met at the foot of the hill a gentleman riding with two or thrée men, and as methought by his habit and his looks, he should be
none of the wisest. He saluted me, and I him: I asked him from whence he came, and whither he would? he answered that he had come from Venice, then from Padua, now was going to Ferrara, and so to his country, which is Sienna: as soon as I know him to be a Siennese, suddenly lifting up mine eyes, as it were with an admiration I said unto him, are you a Siennese, and come to Ferrara? why not, said he: quoth I, half and more with a trembling voice, know you the danger that should ensue if you be known in Ferrara to be a Siennese? he more than half amazed, desired me earnestly to tell him what I meant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I understand not whereto this tendeth.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I believe you, but harken to me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Go too then.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I answered him in this sort: gentleman, because I have heretofore found very courteous entertainment in your country, being a student there, I account myself as it were bound to a Siennese, and therefore if I knew of any mishap towards any of that country, God forbid but I should disclose it: and I marvel that you know not of the injury that your countrymen offered this other day to the ambassadors of county Hercule.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: What tales he telleth me: what appertain these to me?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: If you will hearken a while, you shall find them no tales, but that they appertain to you more than you think for.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Forth.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p:
I told him further, these ambassadors of county Hercule had divers mules, waggons, and charettes, laden with divers costly jewels, gorgeous furniture, and other things which they carried as presents, passing that way to the King of Naples ▪ the which were not only stayed in Sienna by the officers whom you call customers, but searched, ransacked, tossed and turned, and in the end exacted for tribute, as
if they had been the goods of a mean merchant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Whither the devil will he? is it possible that this gear appertaineth any thing to my cause? I find neither head nor foot in it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: O how impatient you are: I pray you stay a while.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Go to yet a while then.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I proceeded, that upon these causes the Duke sent his chancellor to declare the case unto the senate there, of whom he had the most uncourteous answer that ever was heard, whereupon he was so enraged with all of that country, that for revenge he had sworn to spoil as many of them as ever should come to Ferrara, and to send them home in their doublet and their hose.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And I pray thee how couldst thou upon the sudden device or imagine such a lie? and to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: You shall hear by and by a thing as fit for our purpose, as any could have happened.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would fain hear you conclude.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: You would fain leap over the style, before you come at the hedge: I would you had heard me, and seen the gestures that I enforced to make him believe this.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I believe you, for I know you can counterfeit well.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Further I said, the Duke had charged upon great penalties, that the inholders and vitlers should bring word daily of as many Siennese as came to their houses: the gentleman being (As I guessed at the first) a man of small sapientia, when he heard these news, would have turned his horse another way.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: By likelihood he was not very wise when he would believe that of his country, which if it had been true, every man must needs have known it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why not? when he had not been in his country for a month paste, and I told him this had happened within these seven days.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Belike he was of small experience.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I think, of as little as may be: but best of all for our purpose, and good adventure it was, that I met with such an one. Now harken I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Make an end I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: He, as I say, when he hard these words, would have turned the bridle, and I feigning a countenance as though I were somewhat pensive and careful for him, passed a while, and after with a great sigh said to him: gentleman, for the courtesy that (As I said) I have found in your country, and because your affairs shall be the better dispatched, I will find the means to lodge you in my house, and you shall say to every man, that you are a sicilan of Cathanea, your name Philogono, father to me that am in deed of that country and city, called here Erostrato: and I (To pleasure you) will (During your abode here) do you reverence as you were my father.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Out upon me, what a gross headed fool am I? now I perceive whereto this tale tendeth.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Well, and how like you of it?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Indifferently, but one thing I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Marry, that when he hath been here two or thrée days, he shall hear of every man that there is no such thing between the Duke and the town of Sienna.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: As for that let me alone, I do entertain and will entertain him so well, that within these two or thrée days I will disclose unto him all the whole matter, and doubt not but to bring him in for performance of as much as I have promised to Damon: for what hurt can it be to him, when he shall bind a strange name and not his own?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: What, think you he will be entreated to stand hound for a dower of two thousand ducats by the year?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yea why not, if it were ten thousand, as long as he is not in deed the man that is bound?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
Well, if it be so, what shall we be the nearer to our
purpose.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why, when we have done as much as we can, how can we do any more?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And where have you left him?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: At the inn, because of his horses, he and his men shall lie in my house.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Why brought you him not with you?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I thought better to use your advice first.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Well, go take him home, make him all the cheer you can, spare for no cost, I will allow it.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Content, look where he cometh.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Is this he? go meet him, by my truth he looks even like a good soul, he that fisheth for him, might be sure to catch a cod's head: I will rest here a while to decipher him.

div.stage: Erostrato espieth the Scenese and goeth towards him.

div.head: Scaena. ij.
div.stage: The Scenese. Faumlus his servant. Erostrato.
div.p: He that traveleth in this world passeth by many perils.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: You say true sir, if the boat had been a little more laden this morning at the ferry, we had been all drowned, for I think, there are none of us that could have swom.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I speak not of that.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: O you mean the foul way that we had since we ▪ came from this Padua, I promise you, I was afraid twice or thrice, that your mule would have lain fast in the mire.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Jesu, what a blockhead thou art, I speak of the peril we are in presently since we came into this city.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
A great peril I promise you, that we were no sooner
arrived, than you found a friend that brought you from the inn, and lodged you in his own house.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Yea marry, God reward the gentle young man that we met, for else we had been in a wise case by this time. But have done with these tales, and take you heed, and you also sirrah, take heed thatnone of you say we be Siennese, and remember that you call me Philogano of Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Sure I shall never remember these outlandish words I could well remember Haccanea.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I say, Cathanea, and not Haccanea, with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Let another name it then when need is, for I shall never remember it.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Then hold thy peace, and take heed thou name not scene.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: How say you, if I feign myself dumb as I did once in the house of Crisobolus?

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Do as thou thinkest best: but look where cometh the gentleman whom we are so much bound unto.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Welcome, my dear father Philogano.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Gramercy my good son Erostrato.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: That is well said, be mindful of your tongue, for these Ferareses be as crafty as the devil of hell.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: No, no, be you sure we will do as you have bidden us.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: For if you should name scene they would spoil you immediately, and turn you out of the town, with more shame, than I would should befall you for a thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I warrant you, I was giving them warning as I came to you, and I doubt not but they will take good heed.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Yea and trust not the servants of my household to far, for they are Ferareses all, and never knew my father, nor came never in Sicilia: this is my house, will it please you to go in? I will follow.

div.stage: Dulipo tarrieth and espieth the doctor coming in with his man.

div.head: Scaena. iij.
div.p: This gear hath had no evil beginning, if it continue so and fall to happy end. But is not this the silly doctor with the side bonnet, the doting fool, that dare presume to become a suitor to such a peerless paragons? O how covetousness doth blind the common sort of men: Damon more desirous of the dower, than mindful of his gentle and gallant daughter, hath determined to make him his son in law who for his age may he his father in law, and hath greater respect to the abundance of goods, than to his own natural child. He beareth well in mind to fill his own purse, but he little remembreth that his daughter's purse shall be continually empty, unless master doctor fill it with double duck eggs. Alas, I jest and have no joy, I will stand here aside and laugh a little at this lobcock.
div.stage: Dulippo espieth the doctor and his man coming.

div.head: Scaena. iiij.
div.stage: Carion the doctor's man. Cleander. Dulippo.
div.p: Master, what the devil mean you to go seek guests at this time of the day? the mayor's officers have dined ere this time, which are always the last in the market.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I come to seek Pasiphilo, to the end he may dine with me.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: As though six mouths and the cat for the seventh, be not sufficient to eat an harlotry shotterel, a pennyworth of cheese, and half a score spurlings, this is all the dainties you have dressed for you and your family.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ah greedy gut, art thou afeard thou shalt want?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: I am afeard in deed, it is not the first time I have found it so.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Shall I make some sport with this gallant? what shall I say to him?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou art afeard belike that he will eat thee and the rest.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Nay, rather that he will eat your mule, both hair and hide.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hear and hide? and why not flesh and all?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Because she hath none, if she had any flesh, I think you had eaten her yourself by this time.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: She may thank you then, for your good attendance.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Nay she may thank you for your small allowance.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: In faith now let me alone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hold thy peace drunken knave, and espy me Pasiphilo.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Since I can do no better, I will set such a stance between him and Pasiphilo, that all this town shall not make them friends.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Could you not have sent to seek him, but you must come yourself? surely you come for some other purpose, for if you would have had Pasiphilo to dinner, I warrant you he would have tarried here an hour since.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, here is one of Damon's servants, of him I shall understand where he is: good fellow art not thou one of Damon's servants?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yes sir, at your commandment.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Gramercy, tell me then, hath Pasiphilo been there this day or no?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yes sir, and I think he be there still, ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What laughest thou?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At a thing, that every man may not laugh at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Talk, that Pasiphilo had with my master this day.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What talk I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I may not tell it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Doth it concern me?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay I will say nothing.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tell me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I can say no more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I would but know if it concern me, I pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I would tell you, if I were sure you would not tell it again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Believe me I will keep it close: carrion give us leave a little, go aside.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: If my master should know that it came by me, I were better die a thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He shall never know it, say on.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, but what assurance shall I have?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I lay thee my faith and honesty in pawn.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: A pretty pawn, the fulkers will not lend you a farthing on it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea, but amongst honest men it is more worth than gold.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea marry sir, but where be they? but will you needs have me to tell it unto you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea I pray thee if it any thing appertain to me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yes it is of you, and I would gladly tell it you, because I would not have such a man of worship so scorned by a villain ribald.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I pray thee tell me then.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I will tell you so that you will swear never to tell it to Pasiphilo, to my master, nor to any other body.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Surely it is some toy devised to get some money of him.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I think I have a book here.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
If he knew him as well as I, he would never go about it, for he may as soon get one of his tooth from his
jaws with a pair of pinchers, as a penny out of his purse with such a conceit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Here is a letter will serve the turn: I swear to thee by the contents hereof never to disclose it to any man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: I will tell you, I am sorry to see how Pasiphilo doth abuse you, persuading you that always he laboureth for you, where in deed, he lieth on my master continually, as it were with tooth and nail for a stranger, a scholar, born in Sicilia they call him Roscus or arse-kiss, he hath a mad name I can never hit upon it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And thou reckonest it as madly: is it not Erostrato?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: That same, I should never have remembered it: and the villain speaketh all the evil of you that can be devised.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: To my master, yea and to Polynesta herself sometimes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is it possible, ah slave, and what saith he?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: More evil than I can imagine: that you are the miserablest and most niggardly man that ever was.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sayeth Pasiphilo so by me?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And that as often as he cometh to your house, he is like to die for hunger, you fare so well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That the devil take him else.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And that you are the testiest man, and most divers to please in the whole world, so that he cannot please you unless he should even kill himself with continual pain.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O devilish tongue.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Furthermore, that you cough continually and spit, so that a dog cannot abide it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I never spit nor cough more than thus, who, who, and that but since I caught this murr, but who is free from it?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: You say true sir, yet further he say, your arm holes stink, your feet worse than they, and your breath worst of all.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: If I quite him not for this gear.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And that you are bursen in the cods.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O villain, he lieth, and if I were not in the street thou shouldst see them.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: And he saith, that you desire this young gentlewoman, as much for other men's pleasure as for your own.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What meaneth he by that?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Peradventure that by her beauty, you would entice many young men to your house.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Young men? to what purpose?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Nay, guess you that.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is it possible that Pasiphilo speaketh thus of me?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, and much more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And doth Damon believe him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Yea, more than you would think, in such sort, that long ere this, he would have given you a flat repulse, but Pasiphilo entreated him to continue you a suitor for his advantage.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How for his advantage?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Marry, that during your suit he might still have some reward for his great pains.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He shall have a rope, and yet that is more than he deserveth: I had thought to have given him these hose when I had worn them a little nearer, but he shall have a. etc.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: In good faith sir, they were but lost on him. Will you any thing else with me sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, I have heard to much of thee already.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Then I will take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Farewell, but tell me, may I not know thy name?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Sir, they call me foul fall you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: An ill favoured name by my truth, art thou this country man?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: No sir, I was born by a castle men call scab catch you, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Farewell, o God how have I been abused? what a
spokesman? what a messenger had I provided?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why sir, will you tarry for Pasiphilo till we die for hunger?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Trouble me not, that the devil take you both.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: These news whatsoever they be, like him not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Art thou so hungry yet? I pray to God thou he never satisfied.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: By the mass no more I shall as long as I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Go with mischance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yea, and a mischief to you, and to all such covetous wretches.

div.head: Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Dalio the cook. Crapine the lackey ▪ Erostrato. Dulippo.
div.p: By that time we come to the house, I trust that of these xx. eggs in the basket we shall find but very few whole, but it is a folly to talk to him: what the devil, wilt thou never lay that stick out of thy hand? he fighteth with the dogs, beateth the bears, at every thing in the street he findeth occasion to tarry, if he spy a slipstring by the way such another as himself, a page, a lackey or a dwarf, the devil of hell cannot hold him in chains, but he will be doing with him: I cannot go two steps, but I must look back for my younker: go to halter sack, if you break one egg I may chance break.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What will you break? your nose in mine arse.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ah beast.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: If I be a beast, yet I am no horned beast.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Is it even so? is the wind in that door? If I were unloaded I would tell you whether I be a horned beast or no.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You are always laden either with wine or with ale.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Ah spiteful boy, shall I suffer him?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ah cowardly beast, darest thou strike and say never a word?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: Well, my master shall know of this gear, either he shall redress it, or he shall lose one of us.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Tell him the worst thou canst by me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What noise, what a rule is this?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Marry sir, he striketh me because I tell him of his swearing.

sp.speaker: Dal
sp.p: The villain lieth deadly, he reviles me because I bid him make haste.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Holla: no more of this. Dalio, do you make in a readiness those pigeons, stock doves, and also the breast of veal: and let your vessel be as clear as glass against I return, that I may tell you which I will have roasted, and which boiled. Crapine, lay down that basket and follow me. O that I could tell where to find Pasiphilo, but look where he cometh that can tell me of him.

sp.speaker: Dul.
sp.p: What have you done with Philogano your father?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I have left him within, I would fain speak with Pasiphilo, can you tell me where he is?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: He dined this day with my master, but whether he went from thence I know not, what would you with him?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: I would have him go tell Damon that Philogano my father is come and ready to make assurance of as much as he will require. Now shall I fetch master doctor a school point, he traveleth to none other end but to catch cornua, and he shall have them, for as old as he is, and as many subtleties as he hath learned in the law, he can not go beyond me one ace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: O dear friend, go thy ways seek Pasiphilo, find him out, and conclude somewhat to our contentation.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: But where shall I find him?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At the feasts if there be any, or else in the market with the poulters or the fishmongers.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What should he do with them?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Marry he watcheth whose caters buy the best meat, if any buy a fat capon, a good breast of veal, fresh salmon or any such good dish, he followeth to the house, and either with some news, or some stale jest he will be sure to make himself a jest.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: In faith, and I will seek there for him.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Then must you needs find him, and when you have done I will make you laugh.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Whereat?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At certain sport I made today with master doctor.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: And why not now?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: No it asketh further leisure, I pray thee dispatch, and find out Pasiphilo that honest man.

div.head: Scaena. ij.
div.p:
This amorous cause that hangeth in controversy between dominae doctor and me, may be compared to them that play at primero, of whom some one peradventure shall lose a great sum of money before he win one stake, and at last half in anger shall set up his rest, win it, and after that another, another, and another, till at last he draw themost part of the money to his heap, theother by little and little still diminishing his rest, till at last he be come as near the brink, as erst theother was, yet again peradventure fortune smiling on him, he shall as it were by piece meal, pull out theguts of his fellows bags, and bring him barer than he himself was tofore, and so in play continue still, (Fortune favouring now this way now thatway) till at last theone of them is left with as many crosses as God hath brothers: oh how often have I thought myself sure of the upper hand herein? but I triumphed before the victory: and then how oft again have I thought the field lost? Thus have I been tossed now over, now under,
even as fortune list to whirl the wheel, neither sure to win nor certain to lose the wager: and this practice that now my servant hath devised, although hitherto it hath not succeeded amiss, yet can I not count myself assured of it, for I fear still that one mischance or other will come and turn it topsy-turvy . But look where my master cometh.
div.stage: Damon coming in, espieth Dulippo and calleth him.

div.head: Scaena. iij.
div.stage: Damon. Dulippo. Nevola, and two more servants.
div.p: Dulipo.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go in and bid Nevola and his fellows come hither that I may tell them what they shall go about, and go you into my study, there upon the shelf you shall find a roll of writings which John of the Deane made to my father, when he sold him the grange farm, endorsed with both their names: bring it hither to me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Go, I will prepare other manner of writings for you than you are aware of. O fools that trust any man but themselves now adays, o spiteful fortune, thou dost me wrong I think, that from the depth of hell pit thou hast sent me this servant to be the subversion of me and all mine, come hither sirs and hear what I shall say unto you: go in to my study, where you shall find Dulipo, step to him all at once, take him and with a cord that I have laid on the table for the nonce, bind him hand and foot, carry him into the dungeon under the steers, make fast the door and bring me the key, it hangeth by upon a pin ou the wall, dispatch and do this gear as privily as you can, and thou Nevola come hither to me again with speed.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Well sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Alas how shall I be revenged of this extreme despite? if I punish my servant according to his devilish deserts, I shall heap further cares upon mine own head, for to such detestable offences no punishment can seem sufficient, but only death: and in such cases it is not lawful for a man to be his own carver, the laws are ordained, and officers appointed to minister justice for the redress of wrongs: and if to the potestates I complain me, I shall publish mine own reproach to the world: yea, what should it prevail me to use all the punishments that can be devised? the thing once done can not be undone. My daughter is deflowered, and utterly dishonested, how can I then wipe that blot off my brow? and on whom shall I seek revenge? Alas, alas, I myself have been the cause of all these cares, and have deserved to bear the punishment of all these mishaps. Alas, I should not have committed my dearest darling in custody to so careless a creature as this old nurse: for we see by common proof, that these old women be either peevish, or too pitiful: either easily inclined to evil, or quickly corrupted with bribes and rewards. O wife, my good wife (That now liest cold in the grave) now may I well bewail the want of thee, and mourning now may I bemoan that I miss thee: if thou hadst lived, such was thy government of the least things, that thou wouldst prudently have provided for the preservation of this pearl: a costly jewel may I well account her, that hath been my chief comfort in youth, and is now become the corrosive of mine age. O Polynesta, full evil hast thou requited the clemency of thy careful father, and yet to excuse thee guiltless before God, and to condemn thee guilty before the world, I can count none other but my wretched self the caitiff and causer of all my cares: for of all the duties that are requisite in humane life, only obedience is by the parents to be required of the child, where on theother
side the parents are bound, first to beget them, than to bring them forth, after to nourish them, to preserve them from bodily perils in the cradle, from danger of soul by godly education, to match them in comfort inclined to virtue, to banish them all idle and wanton company, to allow them sufficient for their sustentation, to cut of excess the open gate of sin, seldom or never to smile on them unless it be to their encouragement in virtue, and finally, to provide them marriages in time convenient, lest neglected of us, they learn to set either to much or to little by themselves: five years are past since I might have married her, when by continual excuses I have prolonged it to my own perdition: alas, I should have considered, she is a collop of my own flesh, what should I think to make her a Princess? Alas alas, a poor kingdom have I now caught to endue her with: it is too true, that of all sorrows this is the head source and chief fountain of all furies: the goods of the world are incertain, the gains to be rejoiced at, and the loss not greatly to be lamented, only the children cast away, cutteth the parent's throat with the knife of inward care, which knife will kill me surely, I make none other account.

div.stage: Damon's servants come to him again.

div.head: Scaena. iiij.
div.p: Sir, we have done as you bad us, and here is the key.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, go then Nevola and seek master Casteling the jailer, he dwelleth by s. Antony's gate, desire him to lend me a pair of the fetters he useth for his prisoners, and come again quickly.

sp.speaker: Ne
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Hear you, if he ask what I would do with them, say you can not tell, and tell neither him nor any other, what
is become of Dulipo.

div.p: I warrant you sir. Fie upon the devil, it is a thing almost unpossible for a man now a day's to handle money but the metal will stick on his fingers: I marvelled always at this fellow of mine Dulipo, that of the wages he received, he could maintain himself so bravely apparelled, but now I perceive the cause, he had the disbursing and receit of all my master's affairs, the keys of the granary, Dulipo here, Dulipo there, in favour with my master, in favour with his daughter, what would you more, he was magister fac totum, he was as fine as the crusado, and we silly wretches as course as canvas: well, behold what it is come to in the end,pasi. subitò et improviso venit. he had been better to have done less.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Thou sayest true Nevola, he hath done to much in deed.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: From whence comest thou in the devil's name?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Out of the same house thou camest from, but not out of the same door.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: We had thought thou hadst been gone long since.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: When I arose from the table, I felt a rumbling in my belly, which made me run to the stable, and there I fell on sleep upon the straw, and have line there ever since: and thou, whether goest thou?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: My master hath sent me on an errand in great haste.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Whether I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Nay I may not tell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
As though I need any further instructions: oh God what news I hard even now, as I lay in the stable: oh good Erostrato and poor Cleander, that have so earnestly striven for this damsel, happy is he that can get her I promise you, he shall be sure of more than one at a clap that catcheth her, either Adam or Eve within her belly: o God how men may be deceived in a woman: who would have believed the contrary but that she had been a virgin? ask the neighbours and you shall hear very good report of her, mark her behaviours and you would have judged her very maidenly, seldom seen
abroad but in place of prayer, and there very devout, and no gazer at outward sights, no blazer of her beauty above in the windows, no stall at the door for the bypassers: you would have thought her a holy young woman. But much good do it you dominae doctor, he shall be sure to lack no corn in a dear year, whatsoever he have with her else: I beshrew me if I let the marriage any way. But is not this the old scabbed quean that I heard disclosing all this gear to her master, as I stood in the stable ere now? it is she. Whither goeth Psiteria?

div.head: Scaena. v.
div.p: To a gossip of mine hereby.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What? to tattle of the goodly stir that thou keptst concerning Polynesta.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: No, no: but how knew you of that gear?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You told me.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: I? when did I tell you?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Even now when you told it to Damon, I both saw you and heard you, though you saw not me: a good part I promise you, to accuse the poor wench, kill the old man with care, over and besides the danger you have brought Dulipo and the nurse unto, and many more, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: In deed I was to blame, but not so much as you think.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And how not so much did I not hear you tell?

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p:
Yes, but I will tell you how it came to pass: I have known for a great while, that this Dulipo and Polynesta have been together, and all by the means of the nurse, yet I held my peace, and never told it. Now this other day the nurse fell on scolding with me, and twice or thrice called me drunken old whore, and such names that it was too bad: and I called her bawd, and told her that I
knew well enough how often she had brought Dulipo to Polynesta's bed: yet all this while I thought not that anybody had heard me, but it befell clean contrary, for my master was on the other side of the wall, and heard all our talk, whereupon he sent for me, and forced me to confess all that you heard.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: And why wouldst thou tell him? I would not for. Etc.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: Well, if I had thought my master would have taken it so, he should rather have killed me?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Why? how could he take it?

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: Alas, it pitieth me to see the poor young woman how she weeps, wails, and tears her hear, not esteeming her own life half so dear as she doth poor Dulipo's: and her father, he weeps on the other side, that it would pierce an heart of stone with pity: but I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Go that the gonne powder consume the old trot.

div.head: Scaena. i
div.p:
What shall I do? Alas what remedy shall I find for my rueful estate? what escape, or what excuse may I now devise to shift over our subtle supposes? for though to this day I have usurped the name of my master, and that without check or control of any man, now shall I be openly deciphered, and that in the sight of every man: now shall it openly be known, whether I be Erostrato the gentleman, or Dulipo the servant: we have hitherto played our parts in abusing others, but now cometh the man that will not be abused, the right Philogono the right father of the right Erostrato, going to seek Pasiphilo, and hearing that he was at the water gate, behold I espied my servant Litio, and
by and by my old master Philogano setting forth his first step on land, I to fuge and away hither as fast as I could to bring word to the right Erostrato, of his right father Philogano, that to so sudden a mishap some subtle shift might be upon the sudden devised. But what can be imagined to serve the turn, although we had a month's respite to beat our brains about it, since we are commonly known, at the least supposed in this town, he for Dulipo, a slave and servant to Damon, and I for Erostrato a gentleman and a student? But behold, run Crapine to yonder old woman before she get within the doors, and desire her to call out Dulipo: but hear you? if she ask who would speak with him, say thyself and none other.
div.stage: Erostrato espieth Psiteria coming, and sendeth his lackey to her.

div.head: Scaena. ij.
div.p: Honest woman, you gossip, thou rotten whore, hearest thou not old witch?

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: A rope stretch your young bones, either you must live to be as old as I, or be hanged while you are young.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I pray thee look if Dulipo be within.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: Yes that he is I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Desire him then to come hither and speak a word with me, he shall not tarry.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: Content yourself, he is otherwise occupied.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yet tell him so gentle girl.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: I tell you he is busy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why is it such a matter to tell him so, thou crooked crone?

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: A rope stretch you marry.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A pocks eat you marry.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: Thou wilt be hanged I warrant thee, if thou live to it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And thou wilt be burned I warrant thee, if the canker consume thee not.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: If I come near you hempstring, I will teach now to sing sol fa.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Come on, and if I get a stone I will scare crows with you.

sp.speaker: Ps.
sp.p: Go with a mischief, I think thou be some devil that would tempt me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Crapine: hear you? come away, let her go with a vengeance, why come you not? Alas look where my master Philogano cometh: what shall I do? where shall I hide me? he shall not see me in these clothes, nor before I have spoken with the right Erostrato.

div.stage: Erostrato espieth Phylogano coming, and runneth about to hide him.

div.head: Scaena. iij.
div.stage: Philogano. Ferrarese the inn keeper. Litio a servant.
div.p: Honest man it is even so: be you sure there is no love to be compared like the love of the parents towards their children, it is not long since I thought that a very weighty matter should not have made me come out of Sicilia, and yet now I have taken this tedious toil and travail upon me, only to see my son, and to have him home with me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: By my faith sir it hath been a great travail in deed and to much for one of your age?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea be you sure: I came in company with certain gentlemen of my country, who had affairs to dispatch as far as to Ancona, from thence by water to Ravenna, and from Ravenna hither, continually against the tide.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yea, and I think thatyou had but homely lodging by theway.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
The worst that ever man had, but that was nothing to the stir that thesearchers kept with me when I came aboard theship, Jesus how often they untrussed my male and ransacked
a little capcase that I had, tossed and turned all that was within it, searched my bosom, yea my breeches, that I assure you I thought they would have flayed me to search between the fell and the flesh for farthings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sure I have heard no less, and that the merchants bob them some times, but they play the knaves still.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea be you well assured, for such an office is the inheritance of a knave, and an honest man will not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Well, this passage shall seem pleasant unto you when you shall find your child in health and well: but I pray you sir why did you not rather send for him into Sicilia, than to come yourself, specially since you had none other business? peradventure you had rather endanger yourself by this noisome journey, than hazard to draw him from his study.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nay, that was not thematter, for I had rather have him give over his study altogether and come home.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Why? if you minded not to make him learned, to what end did you send him hither at the first?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I will tell you: when he was at home he did as most young men do, he played many mad pranks and did many things that liked me not very well, and I thinking, that by that time he had seen the world, he would learn to know himself better, exhorted him to study, and put in his election what place he would go to. At the last he came hither, and I think he was scarce here so soon as I felt the want of him, in such sort, as from that day to this I have passed few nights without tears: I have written to him very often that he should come home, but continually he refused still, beseeching me to continue his study, wherein he doubted not (As he said) but to profit greatly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: In deed he is very much commended of all men, and specially of the best reputed students.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
I am glad he hath not lost his time, but I care not
greatly for so much knowledge, I would not be without the sight of him again so long, for all the learning in the world. I am old now, and if God should call me in his absence, I promise you I think it would drive me into desperation.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: It is commendable in a man to love his children, but to be so tender over them is more womanlike?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well, I confess it is my fault: and yet I will tell you another cause of my coming hither, more weighty than this. Divers of my country have been here since he came hither, by whom I have sent unto him, and some of them have been thrice, some four or five times at his house, and yet could never speak with him: I fear he applies his study so, that he will not lose the minute of an hour from his book. What, alas, he might yet talk with his countrymen for a while, he is a young man, tenderly brought up, and if he fare thus continually night and day at his book, it may be enough to drive him into a frenzy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: In deed, enough were as good as a feast: lo you sir, here is your son Erostrato's house, I will knock.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea, I pray you knock.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: They hear not.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Knock again.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I think they be on sleep.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p: If this gate were your grandfather's soul, you could not knock more softly, let me come: ho, ho, is there anybody within?

div.stage: Dalio cometh to the window, and there maketh them answer.

div.head: Scaena. iiij.
div.stage: Dalio the cook. Ferarese thinholder. Philogano. Litio his man.
div.p: What devil of hell is there? I think he will break the gates in pieces.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Marry fir, we had thought you had been on sleep within, and therefore we thought best to make you: what doth Erostrato?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: He is not within.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Open the door good fellow I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: If you think to lodge here, you are deceived I tell you, for here are guests enough already.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: A good fellow, and much for thy master's honesty by our lady: and what guests I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Here is Philogano my master's father, lately come out of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Thou speakest truer than thou art aware of, he will be, by that time thou hast opened the door: open I pray thee heartily.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: It is a small matter for me to open the door, but here is no lodging for you, I tell you plain, the house is full.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Of whom?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I told you: here is Philogano my master's father come from Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And when came he?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: He came thrée hours since, or more, he alighted at the angel, and left his horses there: afterwards my master brought him hither.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Good fellow, I think thou haste good sport to mock me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay, I think you have good sport to make me tarry here, as though I have nothing else to do: I am matched with an unruly mate in the kitchen, I will go look to him another while.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I think he be drunken.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sure he seems so: see you not how red he is about the gills?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Abide fellow, what Philogano is it whom thou talkest of?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: An honest gentleman, father to Erostrato my master.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And where is he?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Here within.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: May we see him?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I think you may if you be not blind.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Go to, go tell him here is one would speak with him.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Marry that I will willingly do.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I can not tell what I should say to this gear, Litio what thinkest thou of it?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: I cannot tell you what I should say sir, the world is large and long, there may be more Philoganos and more Erostratos than one, yea and more Ferrara's, more Sicilias, and more Cathaneas: peradventure this is not that Ferrara which you sent your son unto.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peradventure thou art a fool, and he was another that answered us even now. But be you sure honest man, that you mistake not the house?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Nay, than god help, think you I know not Erostratos house? yes, and himself also: I saw him here no longer since than yesterday: but here comes one that will tell us tidings of him. I like his countenance better than the others that answered at the window erewhile.

div.stage: Dalio dravveth his head in at the window, the Scenese cometh out.

div.head: Scaena. v.
div.p: Would you speak with me sir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea sir, I would fain know whence you are.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Sir I am a Sicilian, at your commandment.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What part of Sicilia?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Of Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What shall I call your name?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: My name is Philogano.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What trade do you occupy?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Merchandise.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What merchandise brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: None, I came only to see a son that I have here, whom I saw not these two years.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What call they your son?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Erostrato.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is Erostrato your son?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Yea verily.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And are you Philogano.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And a merchant of Cathanea?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: What need I tell you so often? I will not tell you a lie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes, you have told me a false lie, and thou art a villain and no better.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Sir, you offer me great wrong with these injurious words.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Nay, I will do more than I have yet proffered to do, for I will prove thee a liar, and a knave to take upon thee that thou art not.

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Sir I am Philogano of Cathenea, out of all doubt, if I were not I would be loath to tell you so.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O, see the boldness of this brute beast, what a brazen face he setteth on it?

sp.speaker: Sce.
sp.p: Well, you may believe me of you list: what wonder you?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I wonder at thy impudency, for thou, nor nature that framed thee, can ever counterfeit thee to be me, ribald villain, and lying wretch that thou art.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Shall I suffer a knave to abuse my master's father thus? hence villain, hence, or I will sheathe this good falchion in your paunch: if my master Erostrato find you prating here on this fashion to his father, I would not be in your coat
for more coney skins than I got these twelve months: come you in again sir, and let this cur bark here till he burst.

div.stage: Dalio pulleth the Scenese in at the doors.

div.head: Scaena. vi.
div.p: Litio, how likest thou this gear?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sir, I like it as evil as may be, but have you not often heard tell of the falsehood of Ferrara, and now may you see, it falleth out accordingly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Friend, you do not well to slander the city, these men are no Ferrareses you may know by their tongue.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Well, there is never a barrel better herring, between you both: but in deed your officers are most to blame, that suffer such faults to escape unpunished.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What know the officers of this? think you they know of every fault?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Nay, I think they will know as little as may be, specially when they have no gains by it, but they ought to have their ears as open to hear of such offences, as the Ingates be to receive guests.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hold thy peace fool.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: By the mass I am afeard that we shall be proved fools both two.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: I would think best we should go seek Erostrato himself.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I will wait upon you willingly, and either at the schools, or at the convocations, we shall find him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: By our lady I am weary, I will run no longer about to seek him, I am sure hither he will come at the last.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Sure, my mind gives me that we shall find a new Erostrato
ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Look where he is, whether runs he? stay you awhile, I will go tell him that you are here: Erostrato, Erostrato, ho Erostrato, I would speak with you.

div.stage: Erostrato is espied upon the stage running about.

div.head: Scaena. vii.
div.stage: Feigned Erostrato. Ferrarese. Philogano. Litio. Dalio.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Now can I hide me no longer, alas what shall I do? I will set a good face on, to bear out the matter.

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: O Erostrato, Philogano your father is come, of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Tell me that I know not, I have been with him and seen him already.

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: Is it possible? and it seemeth by him that you know not of his coming.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why, have you spoken with him? when saw you him I pray you?

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: Look you where he stands, why go you not to him? Look you Philogano, behold your dear son Erostrato.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Erostrato? this is not Erostrato, this seemeth rather to been Dulipo, and it is Dulipo in deed.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Why, doubt you of that?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: What saith this honest man?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Marry sir, in deed you are so honourably clad, it is no marvel if you look big.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: To whom speaketh he?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What, God help, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: As far as I remember sir, I never saw you before.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hark Litio, here is good gear, this honest man will not know me.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Gentleman, you take your marks amiss.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Did I not tell you of the falsehood of Ferrara master? Dulipo hath learned to play the knave indifferently well since he came hither.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Peace I say.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Friend, my name is not Dulipo, ask you through out this town of great and small, they know me: ask this honest man that is with you, if you will not believe me.
