sp.speaker: Ferra.
sp.p: In deed, I never knew him otherwise called than Erostrato, and so they call him, as many as know him.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Master, now you may see the falsehood of these fellows, this honest man your host, is of counsel with him, and would face us down that it is Erostrato: beware of these mates.

sp.speaker: Fera.
sp.p: Friend, thou dost me wrong to suspect me, for sure I never heard him otherwise called than Erostrato.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p:
What name could you hear me called by, but
by my right name? But I am wise enough to stand prating here with this old man, I think he be mad.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ah runagate, ah villain traitor, dost thou use thy master thus? what hast thou done with my son villain?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Doth this dog bark here still? and will you suffer him master thus to revile you?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Come in, come in, what wilt thou do with this pestle?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I will rap the old cackabed on the costard.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Away with it, and you sirrah, lay down these stones, come in at door every one of you, bear with him for his age, I pass not of his evil words.

div.stage: Erostrato taketh all his servants in at the doors.

div.head: Scaena. viij.
div.p: Alas, who shall relieve my miserable estate? to whom shall I complain, since he whom I brought up of a child, yea and cherished him as if he had been mine own, doth now utterly deny to know me? and you whom I took for an honest man, and he that should have brought me to the sight of my son, are compact with this false wretch, and would face me down that he is Erostrato. Alas, you might have some compassion of mine age, to the misery I am now in, and that I am a stranger desolate of all comfort in this country, or at the least, you should have feared the vengeance of God the supreme judge (Which knoweth the secrets of all hearts) in bearing this false witness with him, whom heaven and earth do know to be Dulipo and not Erostrato.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: If there be many such witness in this country, men may go about to prove what they will in controversies here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Well sir, you may judge of me as it pleaseth you, and how the matter cometh to pass I know not, but truly, ever since he came first hither, I have known him by the name of Erostrato theson of Philogano a Cathanese, now whether he be so in deed, or whether he be Dulipo, (As you allege) let that be proved by them that knew him before he came hither. But I protest before god, that which I have said, is neither a matter compact with him, nor any other, but e'en as I have heard him called and reputed of all men.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Out and alas, he whom I sent hither with my son to be his servant, and to give attendance on him, hath either cut his throat, or by some evil means made him away, and hath not only taken his garments, his books, his money, and that which he brought out of Sicilia with him, but usurpeth his name also, and turneth to his own commodity the bills of exchange that I have always allowed for my son's expenses, o miserable Philogano, o unhappy old man: o eternal god, is there no judge? no officer? no higher powers whom I may complain unto for redress of these wrongs?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yes sir, we have potestates, we have judges, and above all, we have a most just prince, doubt you not, but you shall have justice if your cause be just.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Bring me then to the judges, to the potestates, or to whom you think best: for I will disclose a part of the greatest knavery, a farthel of the foulest falsehood that ever was heard of.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sir, he that will go to the civil law, must be sure of four things: first, a right and a just cause: then a righteous doctor to plead: next, favour coram judice: and above all, a good purse to procure it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I have not heard, that the law hath any respect to favour, what you mean by it I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Have you no regard to his words, he is but a 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I pray you sir, let him tell me what is favour?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Favour call I, to have a friend near about the judge, who may so solicit thy cause, as if it be right, speedy sentence may ensue without any delays: if it be not good, than to prolong it, till at the last, thine adversary being weary, shall be glad be compound with thee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Of thus much (Although I never heard thus much in this country before) doubt you not Philogano, I will bring you to an advocate that shall speed you accordingly.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Then shall I give myself, as it were a prey to the doctors, whose insatiable jaws I am not able to feed, although I had here all the goods and lands which I possess in mine own country, much less being a stranger in this misery. I know their cautels of old: at the first time I come they will so extol my cause, as though it were already won: but within in sevennight or ten days, if I do not continually feed them as the crow doth her brats, twenty times in an hour, they will begin to wax cold, and to find canels in my cause, saying, that at the first I did not well instruct them: till at the last, they will not only draw the stuffing out of my purse, but the marrow out of my bones.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yea sir, but this man that I tell you of, is half a saint.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: And the other half a devil, I hold a penny.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well said Litio, in deed I have but small confidence in their smooth looks.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Well sir, I think this whom I mean, is no such manner of man: but if he were, there is such hatred and evil will between him and this gentleman (Whether he be Erostrato or Dulipo, whatsoever he be) that I warrant you, he will do whatsoever he can do for you, were it but to spite him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why? what hatred is betwixt them?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p:
They are both in love and suitors to one gentlewoman,
the daughter of a wealthy man in this city.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why? is the villain become of such estimation that he dare presume to be a suitor to any gentlewoman of a good family?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Yea sir out of all doubt.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How call you his adversary?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Cleander, one of the excellentest doctors in our city.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: For god's love let us go to him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Go we then.

div.head: Scaena. i.
div.p: What a mishap was this? that before I could meet with Erostrato, I have light even full in the lap of Philogano, where I was constrained to deny my name, to deny my master, and to feign that I knew him not, to contend with him, and to revile him, in such sort, that hap what hap can, I can never hap well in favour with him again: therefore if I could come to speak with the right Erostrato. I will renounce unto him both habit and credit, and away as fast as I can trudge into some strange country, where I may never see Philogano again. Alas, he that of a little child hath brought me up unto this day, and nourished me as if I had been his own: and in deed (To confess thetroth) I have no father to trust unto but him. But look where Pasiphilo cometh, the fittest man in the world to go on my message to Erostrato.
div.stage: Erostrato espieth Pasiphilo coming towards him.

div.head: Scaena. ij.
div.p:
Two good news have I heard today already, one that Erostrato prepared a great feast this night: theother, that
he seeketh for me, and I to ease him of his travail, lest he should run up and down seeking me, and because no man loveth better than I to have an errand where good cheer is, come in post hast even home to his own house: and look where he is.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Pasiphilo, thou must do one thing for me if thou love me.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: If I love you not, who loves you, command me?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Go then a little there, to Damon's house, ask for Dulipo, and tell him.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Wot you what? I cannot speak with him, he is in prison.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: In prison? how cometh that to pass? where is he in prison?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: In a vile dungeon there within his master's house.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Canst thou tell wherefore?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Be you content to know he is in prison, I have told you to much.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: If ever you will do any thing for me, tell me.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: I pray you desire me not, what were you the better if you knew?

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: More than thou thinkest Pasiphilo by god.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Well, and yet it stands me upon more than you think, to keep it secret

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Why Pasiphilo, is this the trust I have had in you? are these the fair promises you have always made me?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: By the mass I would I had fasted this night with master doctor, rather than have come hither.

sp.speaker: Ero
sp.p: Well Pasiphilo, either tell me, or at few words never think to be welcome to this house from hence forth.

sp.speaker: Pas
sp.p: Nay, yet I had rather lose all the gentlemen in this town, but if I tell you any thing that displease you, blame nobody but yourself now.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p:
There is nothing can grieve me more than Dulipo's
mishap, no not mine own, and therefore I am sure thou canst tell me no worse tidings.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Well, since you would needs have it, I will tell you: he was taken a-bed with your beloved Polynesta.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Alas, and doth Damon know it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: An old trot in the house disclosed it to him, whereupon he took both Dulipo and the nurse which hath been the broker of all this bargain, and clapped them both in a cage, where I think they shall have sour sops to their sweet meats.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Pasiphilo, go thy ways into the kitchen, command the cook to boil and roast what liketh thee best, I make thee supra visor of this supper.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By the mass if you should have studied this seven-night, you could not have appointed me an office to please me better, you shall see what dishes I will devise.

div.head: Scaena. iij.
div.p:
I was glad to rid him out of the way, lest he should see me burst out these swelling tears, which hitherto with great pain I have prisoned in my breast, and lest he should hear the echo of my doubled sighs, which bounce from the bottom of my heavy heart. O cursed I, oh cruel fortune, that so many dispersed griefs as were sufficient to subvert a legion of lovers, hast suddenly assembled within my careful carcase to fret this fearful heart in sunder with desperation: thou that hast kept my master all his youth within the realm of Sicilia ▪ reserving the wind and waves in a temperate calm (As it were at his command) now to convey his aged limbs hither, neither sooner nor later, but even in the worst time that may be: if at any time before thou hadst conducted him, this enterprise had been
cut off without care in the beginning: and if never so little longer thou hadst lingered his journey, this happy day might then have fully finished our drifts and devises. But alas, thou hast brought him e'en in the very worst time, to plunge us all in the pit of perdition. Neither art thou content to entangle me alone in thy ruinous ropes, but thou must also catch the right Erostrato in thy crooked claws, to reward us both with open shame and rebuke. Two years hast thou kept secret our subtle supposes, even this day to decipher them with a sorrowful success. What shall I do? Alas what shift shall I make? it is too late now to imagine any further deceit, for every minute seemeth an hour till I find some succour for the miserable captive Erostrato. Well, since there is no other remedy, I will go to my master Philogano, and to him will I tell the whole truth of the matter, that at the least he may provide in time, before his son feel the smart of some sharp revenge and punishment: this is the best, and thus will I do: yet I know, that for mine own part I shall do bitter penance for my faults forepast: but such is the good will and duty that I bear to Erostrato, as even with the loss of my life I must not stick to adventure any thing which may turn to his commodity. But what shall I do? shall I go seek my master about the town, or shall I tarry his return hither? If I meet him in the streets, he will cry out upon me, neither will he hearken to any thing that I shall say, till he have gathered all the people wondering about me, as it were at an owl. Therefore I were better to abide here, and yet if he tarry long, I will go seek him, rather than prolong the time to Erostratos peril.

div.head: Scaena. iiij.
div.p: Yea dress them, but lay them not to the fire, till they will be ready to sit down: this gear goeth in order: but if I had not gone in, there had fallen a foul fault.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: And what fault I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Marry, Dalio would have laid the shoulder of mutton and the capon both to the fire at once, like a fool, he did not consider, that the one would have more roasting than the other.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Alas, I would this were the greatest fault.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why? and either the one should have been burned before the other had bene roasted, or else he must have drawn them off the spit: and they would have been served to the board either cold or raw.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: Thou hast reason Pasiphilo.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Now sir, if it please you I will go into the town and buy oranges, olives, and capers, for without such sauce the supper were more than half lost.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: There are within already, doubt you not, there shall lack nothing that is necessary.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Since I told him these news of Dulipo, he is clean beside himself: he hath so many hammers in his head, that his brains are ready to burst: and let them break, so I may sup with him tonight , what care I? But is not this dominus noster Cleandrus that cometh before? well said, by my truth we will teach master doctor to wear a cornered cap of a new fashion: by God Polynesta shall be his, he shall have her out of doubt, for I have told Erostrato such news of her, that he will none of her.

div.stage: Cleander and Philogano come in, talking of the matter in controversy.

div.head: Scaena. v.
div.p:
Yea, but how wilt ▪ ye prove that he is not Erostrato, having such presumptions to the contrary? or how shall it be
thought that you are Philogano, when another taketh upon him this same name, and for proof bringeth him for a witness, which hath been ever reputed here for Erostrato?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I will tell you sir, let me be kept here fast in prison, and at my charges let there be some man sent into Sicilia ▪ that may bring hither with him two or thrée of the honestest men in Cathanea and by them let it be proved if I or this other be Philogano, and whether he be Erostrato or Dulipo my servant: and if you find me contrary, let me suffer death for it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I will go salute master doctor.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It will ask great labour and great expenses to prove it this way, but it is the best remedy that I can see.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And reward you as you have deserved.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Then shall be give me your favour continually.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He shall give you a halter, knave and villain that thou art.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I know I am a knave, but no villain, I am your servant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I neither take thee for my servant, nor for my friend.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why? wherein have I offended you sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hence to the gallows knave.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What soft and fair sir, I pray you, I prae sequor, you are mine elder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will be even with you, be you sure, honest man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why sir? I never offended you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, I will teach you: out of my sight knave.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What? I am no dog, I would you wist.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Pratest thou yet villain? I will make thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What will you make me? I see well the more a man doth suffer you, the worse you are.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A villain, if it were not for this gentleman, I would tell you what I.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Villain? nay I am as honest a man as you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thou liest in thy throat knave.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O sir, stay your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: What will you fight? marry come on.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well knave, I will meet with you another time, go your way.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Even when you list sir, I will be your man.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And if I be not even with thee, call me cut.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Nay by the mass, all is one, I care not, for I have nothing: if I had either lands or goods, peradventure you would pull me into the law.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Sir, I perceive your patience is moved.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This villain: but let him go, I will see him punished as he hath deserved. Now to the matter, how said you?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: This fellow hath disquieted you sir, peradventure you would be loath to be troubled any further.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not a whit, say on, and let him go with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I say, let them send at my charge to Cathanea.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea I remember that well, and it is the surest way as this case requireth: but tell me, how is he your servant? and how come you by him? inform me fully in the matter.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I will tell you sir: when the Turks won Otranto.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O, you put me in remembrance of my mishaps.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: For I was driven among the rest out of the town (It is my native country) and there I lost more than ever I shall recover again while I live.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Alas, a pitiful case by saint Anne.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
At that time (As I said) there were certain of our country that scoured those costs upon the seas, with a good bark well appointed for the purpose, and had espial of a Turkey vessel that came laden from thence with great
abundance of riches.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And peradventure most of mine.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: So they boarded them, and in the end overcame them, and brought the goods to Palermo, from whence they came, and amongst other things that they had, was this villain my servant, a boy at that time, I think not past five years old.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas I lost one of that same age there.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And I being there, and liking the child's favour well, proffered them four and twenty ducats for him, and had him.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What? was the child a Turk? or had the Turks brought him from Otranto?

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.p: They said he was a child of Otranto, but what is that to the matter? once xxiiij ducats he cost me, that I wot well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas, I speak it not for that sir, I would it were he whom I mean.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why, whom mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Beware sir, be not too lavish.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Was his name Dulipo then? or had he not another name?

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Beware what you say sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What the devil hast thou to do? Dulipo? no sir, his name was Carino.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Yea, well said, tell all and more to, do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O lord, if it be as I think, how happy were I? and why did you change his name then?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: We called him Dulipo, because when he cried as children do sometimes, he would always cry on that name Dulipo.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Well, than I see well it is my own only child, whom I lost, when I lost my country: he was named Carino after his grandfather, and this Dulipo whom he always remembered in his lamenting, was his foster father
that nourished him and brought him up.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Sir, have I not told you enough of thefalsehood of Ferrara? this gentleman will not only pick your purse, but beguile you of your servant also, and make you believe he is his son.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well goodfellow, I have not used to lie.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Sir no, but every thing hath a beginning.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Fie, Philogano have you not the least suspect that may be of me.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: No marry, but it were good he had the most suspect that may be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, hold thou thy peace a little good fellow. I pray you tell me Philogano had thechild any remembrance of his father's name, his mother's name or thename of his family?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: He did remember them, and could name his mother also, but sure I have forgotten the name.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: I remember it well enough.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tell it then.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Nay, that I will not marry, you have told him too much already.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Tell it I say, if thou can.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: Can? yes by themass I can well enough: but I will have my tongue pulled out, rather than tell it, unless he tell it first: do you not perceive sir, what he goeth about?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, I will tell you then, my name you know already ▪ my wife his mother's name was Sophronia, the house that I came of, they call Spiagia.

sp.speaker: Liti.
sp.p: I never heard him speak of Spiagia but in deed I have heard him say, his mother's name was Sophronia: but what of that? A great matter I promise you, it is like enough that you two have compact together to deceive my master.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What needeth me more evident tokens? this is my son out of doubt whom I lost eightéen years since, and a thousand thousand times have I lamented for him: he should have also a mould on his left shoulder.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: He hath a mould there in deed: and an hole in another place too, I would your nose were in it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Fair words fellow Litio: o I pray you let us go talk with him, oh fortune, how much am I bound to thee if I find my son?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yea how small am I beholden to fortune, that know not where my son is become, and you whom I chose to be mine advocate, will now by the means of this Dulipo become mine adversary?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Sir, let us first go find mine: and I warrant you yours will be found also ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: God grant, go we then.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Since the door is open, I will neither knock nor call, but we will be bold to go in.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Sir, také you heed, lest he lead you to some mischief.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Alas Litio, if my son be lost what care I what become of me?

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Well, I have told you my mind sir, do you as you please.

div.stage: Exeunt: Damon and Psiteria come in.

div.head: Scaena sexta.
div.p: Come hither you old callet, you tattling housewife, that the devil cut out your tongue: tell me, how could Pasiphilo know of this gear but by you?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Sir, he never knew it of me, he was the first that told me of it.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Thou liest old drab, but I would advise you tell me the truth, or I will make those old bones rattle in your skin.

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Sir, if you find me contrary, kill me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why? where should he talk with thee?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: He talked with me of it here in the street.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What did you here?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: I was going to the weavers for a web of cloth you have there.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And what cause could Pasiphilo have to talk of it, unless thou began the matter first?

sp.speaker: Psi.
sp.p: Nay, he began with me sir, reviling me, because I had told you of it: I asked him how he knew of it, and he said he was in the stable when you examined me erewhile.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas, alas, what shall I do then? in at doors old whore, I will pluck that tongue of thine out by the roots one day. Alas it grieveth me more that Pasiphilo knoweth it, than all the rest: he that will have a thing kept secret, let him tell it to Pasiphilo, the people shall know it, and as many as have ears and no more: by this time he hath told it in a hundreth places. Cleander was the first, Erostrato the second, and so from one to another throughout the city. Alas, what dower, what marriage shall I now prepare for my daughter? O poor dolorous Damon, more miserable than misery itself, would god it were true that Polynesta, told me ere while: that he who hath deflowered her, is of no servile estate, as hitherto he hath been supposed in my service: but that he is a gentleman born of a good parentage in Sicilia. Alas, small riches should content me, if he be but of an honest family, but I fear that he hath devised these toys to allure my daughter's love. Well I will go examine her again, my mind giveth me that I shall perceive by her tale whether it be true or not. But is not this Pasiphilo that cometh out of my neighbour's house? what the devil aileth him to leap and laugh so like a fool in the high way?

div.stage: Pasiphilo cometh out of the town laughing.

div.head: Scaena septima.
div.p: O God, that I might find Damon at home.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What the devil would he with me?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: That I may be the first that shall bring him these news.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What will he tell me, in the name of God?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: O lord, how happy am I? look where he is.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What news Pasiphilo, that thou art so merry?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Sir, I am merry to make you glad: I bring you joyful news.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And that I have need of Pasiphilo.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: I know sir, that you are a sorrowful man for this mishap that hath chanced in your house, peradventure you thought I had not known of it: but let it pass, pluck up you sprites, and rejoice, for he that hath done you this injury is so well born, and hath so rich parents, that you may be glad to make him your son in law.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: How knowest thou?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: His father Philogano one of the worthiest men in all Cathanea, is now come to the city, and is here in your neighbour's house.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What, in Erostratos house?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Nay in Dulipo's house, for where you have always supposed this gentleman to be Erostrato, it is not so, but your servant whom you have imprisoned hitherto, supposed to be Dulipo, he is in deed Erostrato, and that other is Dulipo: and thus they have always, even since their first arrival in this city, exchanged names, to the end that Erostrato the master, under the name of Dulipo a servant, might be entertained in your house, and so win the love of your daughter.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, than I perceive it is e'en as Polynesta told me.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Why, did she tell you so?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yea: but I thought it but a tale.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Well, it is a true tale: and here they will be with you by and by, both Philogano this worthy man, and master doctor Cleander.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Cleander? what to do?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Cleander? Why thereby lies another tale, the most fortunate adventure that ever you heard: wot you what? this other Dulipo, whom all this while we supposed to be Erostrato, is found to be the son of Cleander, whom he lost at the loss of Otranto, and was after sold in Sicilia to this Philogano, the strangest case that ever you heard: a man might make a comedy of it, they will come even straight, and tell you the whole circumstance of it themselves.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay I will first go hear the story of this Dulipo, be it Dulipo or Erostrato that I hear within, before I speak with Philogano.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: So shall you do well sir, I will go tell them that they may stay a while, but look where they come.

div.stage: Damon goeth in, Scenese, Cleander and Philogano come upon the stage.

div.head: Scaena. viij.
div.p: Sir, you shall not need to excuse the matter any further, since I have received no greater injury than by words: let them pass like wind, I take them well in worth, and am rather well pleased than offended, for it shall both be a good warning to me another time how to trust every man at the first sight ▪ yea, and I shall have good game hereafter to tell this pleasant story another day in mine own country.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Gentleman, you have reason, and be you sure, that
as many as hear it, will take great pleasure in it, and you Philogano may think, that god in heaven above, hath ordained your coming hither at this present, to the end I might recover my lost son, whom by no other means I could ever have found out.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Surely sir I think no less, for I think that not so much as a leaf falleth from the tree, without the ordinace of god. But let us go seek Damon, for methinketh every day a year, every hour a day, and every minute to much till I see my Erostrato.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I cannot blame you, go we then, Carino take you that gentleman home in the mean time, the fewer the better to be present at such affairs.

div.head: Scaena. ix.
div.p: Master doctor, will you not show me this favour, to tell me the cause of your displeasure?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Gentle Pasiphilo, I must needs confess I have done thee wrong, and that I believed tales of thee, which in deed I find now contrary.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: I am glad then that it proceeded rather of ignorance than of malice.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yea believe me Pasiphilo.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: O sir, but yet you should not have given me such foul words.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Well, content thyself Pasiphilo, I am thy friend as I have always been: for proof whereof, come sup with me to night, and from day to day this seven night be thou my guest: but behold, here cometh Damon out of his house.

div.head: Scaena decima.
div.stage: Cleander. Philogano. Damon. Erostrato. Pasiphilo. Polinesta. Nevola ▪ and other servants.
div.p: We are come unto you sir, to turn your sorrow into joy and gladness: the sorrow, we mean, that of force you have sustained since this mishap of late fallen in your house. But be you of good comfort sir, and assure yourself, that this young man which youthfully and not maliciously hath committed this amorous offence, is very well able with consent of this worthy man his father, to make you sufficient amends, being born in Cathanea of Sicilia, of a noble house, noway inferior unto you, and of wealth (By the report of such as know it) far exceeding that of yours.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: And I here in proper person, do present unto you sir, not only my assured friendship and brotherhood, but do earnestly desire you to accept my poor child (Though unworthy) as your son in law: and for recompense of the injury he hath done you, I proffer my whole lands in dower to your daughter, yea and more would, if more I might.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And I sir, who have hitherto so earnestly desired your daughter in marriage, do now willingly yield up and quite claim to this young man, who both for his years, and for the love he beareth her, is most meetest to be her husband: for where I was desirous of a wife by whom I might have issue, to leave that little which god hath sent me, now have I little need, that (Thanks be to god) have found my dear beloved son, whom I lost of a child at the siege of Otranto.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Worthy gentleman, you friendship, your alliance, and the nobility of your birth are such, as I have much
more cause to desire them of you, than you to request of me that which is already granted: therefore I gladly, and willingly receive the same, and think myself most happy now of all my life past, that I have gotten so towards a son in law to myself, and so worthy a father in law to my daughter, yea and much the greater is my contentation, since this worthy gentleman master Cleander, doth hold himself satisfied. And now behold your son.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.p: O father.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Behold the natural love of the child to the the father, for inward joy he cannot pronounce one word, in steed whereof he sendeth sobs and tears to tell the effect of his inward intention. But why do you abide here abroad? will it please you to go into the house sir?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Pasiphilo hath said well, will it please you to go in sir?

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Here I have brought you sir, both fetters and bolts.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Away with them now.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.p: Yea, but what shall I do with them?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Marry I will tell thee Nevola, to make a right end of our supposes, lay one of those bolts in the fire, and make thee a suppository as long as mine arm, God save the sample. Nobles and gentlemen, if you suppose that our supposes have given you sufficient cause of delight, show some token, whereby we may suppose you are content.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
